user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mutex:
```c
static int mutex(void)
{
	metal_mutex_t lock;
	const int threads = 10;
	int rc;

	metal_mutex_init(&lock);

	rc = metal_run(threads, mutex_thread, &lock);

	metal_mutex_deinit(&lock);

	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mutex:
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}
...
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that assign to or otherwise modify a function parameter variable itself (which would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8). Details by function:

- mutex(void): has no parameters.
- metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg): the parameters are only read; the VLA declaration pthread_t tids[threads] uses the value but does not modify the parameter. No assignments to threads, child, or arg occur.
- metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out): parameters are not reassigned. Casting the void *tids to a local pointer (pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids) creates a local variable and does not modify the parameter. Writing *threads_out = i modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter, which is explicitly allowed by the rule. Passing arg to pthread_create may result in modification of the pointed-to object by the new thread, which is also allowed.
- metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids): parameters are only read; tid_p is a local pointer assigned from the parameter but the parameter itself is not modified.
- mutex_thread(void *arg): the code creates a local pointer (metal_mutex_t *l = arg) and uses it; the parameter arg itself is not reassigned.

Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation under Rule 17.8.
